Printed in PLA, se support angle to 75% so threads are printed without suport.
Coins with diameter up to 2,5cm (1 inch) fit.
No need to keep coins in a certain order.

0 Dump coins in tube.
1 Just keep it at angle and shake the coins into a reasonable stack.
2 Now screw the top in untill the coins are stuck.
3 The top can be protruding or held within the tube.

4 To use the $$$ just unscrew one turn and dump the coins in your palm.
5 GOTO 0

A replacement for the cap for my 5gal gas can, which I lost while fueling up the snow-thrower.  I didn't bother to replicate the bit that slides into a groove to hold it securely, since it is snug enough to hold on its own.  In fact, my first try, which included such a groove (at the wrong end because I'm an idiot) fits so well I just left it at that.)

comments.text: It's only been a few days, and winter days at that, but so far there's absolutely no difference in the cap, inside or out.  No melting, no softening, no pitting, no smoothing, nothing.  I'll report if it has an effect with more time.
comments.author: HunterGreen

comments.text: Still no effects.
comments.author: HunterGreen

comments.text: We're over a year out now, how's it doing? I'm thinking of printing this for my gas can.
comments.author: HunterGreen

comments.text: I only used it for about three months before finding the original cap, but there was absolutely zero hint of any degradation.
comments.author: logicize

comments.text: I'd wager that gas fumes will melt that into nothingness over time.
comments.author: JuliaTruchsess

comments.text: How does it hold up against gasoline? I can't recall offhand if ABS melts with gas or not.
comments.author: Roach570

comments.text: Good question.  I can't find anything online about how ABS holds up to gasoline.  Of course I'm not going to be soaking the cap in gasoline, so it'll only be exposed to the fumes a bit this way.  Even so, it might get soft or something.  I'll have to keep an eye on it.  Of course, come spring the original cap will probably show up (if not sooner) so it only has to hold me until that turns up.

author: mikefitz

remixed_from.author: 626Pilot
remixed_from.title: Dimensional Accuracy Calibration for Delta Printers

description.text:
I have a custom-designed Kossel mini, and was getting frustrated when some prints weren't coming out the way I'd expected. So I used 626Pilot's Dimension Accuracy Calibration, but when I printed the 50mm block, I found that the dimensions in one direction were different from the other direction.

This probably meant that my rods, which are adjustable, were not the same length. My first passes were to take the 50mm block, rotate by 120 degrees (for each tower), print and measure again. This gives an indication as to which rod set may be off, and how to adjust them (lengthen or shorten) in order to try it again.

The calibration process is still under way, but I decided to respin the 50mm block to have tower markings, and have three separate pieces. Measuring across the block from the side the tower number above the 50mm marking will indicate whether the rods need to be adjusted.
Imported the 50mm block .stl file into Tinkercad, added the numbers for the towers, then copied two more, and rotated the block for the desired tower.

This project is related to my CCC (Centro para la Cultura y el Conocimiento, S.A.) course to be a 3D Printing Technician. This design is intended to be used as a stand or display for brushes and makeup.

author: Palmiga

description.text:
Issues of warping and cracking in ABS printing can be solved using a Heated Build Chamber. This kind of chamber is bulky and all the components of the printer (plastics, electronics) undergo a high temperature.

The principle of the proposed solution is to build a heated enclosure around the hot bed, and not as usual around the printer.

The expected advantages are:

  • Printer parts -electronic components,motors . . .- work at room temperarture,
  • No need of extra heating,
  • Less power to heat the bed (up to 50% less).

The enclosure consists of three main parts:

  • 2 insulation sheets that cover the entire hot bed,
  • 2 side plates attached to the printer frame,
  • and 2 Z shutters which follow the movement of the X axis.

Insulation sheets (upper covers) and shutters of the enclosure are fixed to a support consisting of aluminum angles and plastic parts, itself fixed to the X axis rods.Front and rear covers consist of 3 layers of mylar film, PE foam and aluminized plastic film.

see video: https://youtu.be/211JHkUjk4k

This is an improved version of my previous designs:
www.thingiverse.com/thing:997467
www.thingiverse.com/thing:911708

Additional features are:

  • Improved insulation,
  • Simple and easy install/uninstall (nothing to unscrew),
  • Angle distance adjustment.

The X shutters of the previous designs are suppressed and the distance between the angles is reduced to limit the heat losses.

title: CR-10 E3D V6 3Vent Cooling Unit height adjustable

description.text:
CR-10 E3D-V6 cooling unit for three 40mm vents. Inspired by the fang, completely new designed with very close distance to the bed.

The whole unit is, by long holes in the back plate, height adjustable and is screwed onto the bolts of the OEM roller bracket. The funnels are wider than those of the fang, have a natural subdivided shape and provide a very good air flow.

You can use 40x10mm or 40x20mm fans. The middle funnel for the hot end is the thing #2449326, so download that too in order to get all shown parts.

All parts fit well printed at 100% scale. The holes are designed to take 3mm metric screws. For the clamp you need 2x 3mm nuts and slide them into the back plate.
The back plate should be printed with supports (there's a clearing for a screw that needs support).

Update: The back plate got a minor adjustment to sit snug on the CR-10 carrier thingie. nothing dramatic though. Thus named Rel.2.

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,1 - 0,2

Infill:

100%
Designed with 3Ds Max

author: rdp837

description.text: This printer is designed to be very easy to assemble, with a minimum number of parts. It is very easy to use and easy to hack. It has a smaller footprint and larger print area than its predecessor, the Aluminum Mendel.  It is very precise and efficient.  The tradeoff is that it requires some machined parts that may be hard to source if you do not have access to a vertical mill.  For this reason, it is not a good choice for beginners. The y and z axes use machined UHMW inserts that slide directly on the aluminum extrusions.  This gives a rock-solid print bed with very low friction. All forces acing on the printer are carefully balanced for smooth printing.  The low mass extruder is very precise for accurate, clean prints.

See assembly drawings and BOM. Add a bed heater and power supply of your choice. I do not yet have the nuts and bolts on the BOM. I included dxf files for all the parts made from aluminum plate. You can upload these files directly to emachineshop.com and they will laser cut them for you. Get two zBrackets. You will have to do the countersinks yourself. These parts are much cheaper if you can get several people together and order multiple sets. I have included prints if you want to make the parts of aluminum manually. The extruder plate is the hardest. Print out the stl alumPlateV2 and use it as a drill template.
It is possible to print the slides, although they have more friction than UHMW. For this reason, I have included stl files for them. Use silicone spray to reduce wear and friction for printed slides.
The flexMendel follows a few basic design principles. It will be helpful to understand these principles when assembling the printer. The axes are only minimally restrained, there are many places where components need to float or flex. Reciprocating masses are kept low, and forces are carefully balanced. The frame is the sliding mechanism, there is nothing to align. This makes a very efficient, precise machine.
The Y carriage is constrained in the y axis only by the two slides on the right side. They are loosely constrained in the +z direction, gravity holds the carriage down. The single slide on the left floats in the x and +z. Its function is to support the print bed on the left side. If the right y slides are a little loose, you can angle them slightly. The y belt tension helps prevent yaw in the y carriage, and should be run pretty tight.
When the x axis ends are assembled with the smooth rods, care should be taken to make sure that the rods can slide on one end. The x ends are held together by the x belt tension, and can move in and out slightly. This prevents binding of the z axis if the z frame pieces are not perfectly parallel. The top bushings on the x carriage constrain the extruder in y and z. The bottom bushings only constrain the extruder in y. They can flex in z to account for any variation in the distance between the smooth rods.
The threaded z rods are tightly constrained in z by the thrust bearings in the top z rod brackets. They can float slightly in x and y. The nut cap that retains the 8 mm nut in the x ends must not be over tightened or the nut will bind. It should be free to align with the threaded rod. The flex couplings specified should be used, or a substitute that has both radial and axial compliance and uses set screws rather than clamping the rod. The common spiral aluminum couplings have no radial compliance. Finally, the z motor mounts can flex slightly in x. Install the z motors and couplings with the top z rod brackets loosely fastened. Then, run the x axis up to the top and tighten the top z bracket bolts.
Finally, the extruder shaft must be able to float slightly. With the shaft installed in the partially assembled extruder, insert a short length of filament and the shaft will align itself properly. Use the pinch roller if necessary to hold the shaft in place. Then install the large gear on the shaft, leaving approximately 0.5 mm clearance between the gear and aluminum plate. This will prevent twisting of the filament.

comments.author: arejay

comments.text: The common spiral cut clamp style aluminum flex couplings have no radial compliance and tightening them can cause them to distort. I use Misumi flex couplings with set screws.  With this set up and high quality threaded rods, you should have no trouble with z wobble. Make sure to hold tolerance on the z slides to eliminate any source of movement.

Don´t need the conductivity?

Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this:

This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design:

•The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.
•The hardness of 95 shore A and the carbon black filler makes for great print abilities.
•The carbon black filler is an excellent UV stabilizer thus the prints are built to last in very harsh environments.
•The matte black surface finish has a very exclusive look.
•The material feels very nice and dry to touch.
•It´s not too stretchy and will do great for timing belts etc.

print_settings.Notes:: This will cut a pizza like no other!!

description.text:
This is a Pizza Cutter that works.

It's based on a curved cutter that you can cut a 12" Pizza in one go. It has a handle on the top to grip. I have sliced this in Simplify3D which has 40% infill up to 25cm then moves to 100% for blade stability. I have printed this in ABS for the dishwasher as other materials will degrade. The base is slightly flattened so print without raft or supports.

I have seen other pizza cutters but they either have things stuck on them or are difficult to print. This prints as is and is easy to clean.

Let me know your thoughts.

4th Sept Update : My ABS version split during printing. PETG seemed to work a lot better. If someone can find a way to print this in ABS let me know.
19th Sept, PETG melts when the pizza has just come out of the oven. Use ABS for sure.

Anycubic i3 Mega

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

.20

Varied 40% up to 25cm then 100%

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/5cqe3ZaD63C
Egg

Sandwich this between your fan and mount for more concentrated and laminar airflow. This is about as aerodynamic as I could get it. The plate is 7mm thick and the cone is 20mm dia and protrudes another 13mm. The holes are 3mm. I printed one and it actually works well. One is adjusted for a .4mm nozzle, the other is for .2mm. This video inspired this thing https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rDq4KSlZcTo&t=124s Happy Printing! The 30mm fans have a 15mm cone diameter, are 5.25mm thich, and the cone protrudes 9.75mm.
High Compression fans are for situations with airflow restrictions. For the Ducts I recommend using screws that protrude past your fan up to 5mm and adding a non permanent adhesive, like glue stick, in the holes to secure it. The ducts will likely require supports on the sides during printing.

title: Transposition Insulator Pin for standard American threads

description.text:
For those of you fellow insulator collectors out there, have you ever found that you can't get a piece of pin to really solidly hold your two piece transposition insulators together? 3D printing to the rescue!

This is a standard North American-thread insulator pin that's a bit longer than standard and designed to provide solid engagement between the top and bottom pieces of a transposition, making sure they won't fall apart.

Credit to Mat Oransky, who figured out how to make the part elegantly. We've included the Fusion 360 f3d file so if anybody wants it as a starting point, they can.

I think the STL came out in mm when inches were intended. Just scale up by 25.4

title: 3D Printing Terminology Visual Displays
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Created this as a visual aid for newcomers to 3D printing.

Update - Universal GCODES - USE AT OWN RISK:
User jpelc has generously provided 'universal gcodes' that will theoretically print on any printer but this hasn't been tested yet. If you're interested in testing these out, please message me and I can send you the gcodes. They're available at 100%, 75% and 50% scale.

Printer:

Craftbot Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

--On Simplify3D > 'Separate Connected Surfaces' and create a separate process for each corresponding section

--You should be able to use the latest Slic3r to achieve the same results. Once you load the STL into Slic3r, you'll want to first split the parts. Then, you'll be able to select each individual piece, right click > Settings and assign different settings to them by pressing the plus sign.

--I'm still working out whether it's possible to do the same in Cura. I don't think so yet.

--For the Layer Height, I first printed with 1 shell but it turned out better/stronger with 2 shells. The first try had some stringing, but adjusting the start points to the back of the print seemed to resolve that.

--For Bridging, I slowed the speed down to 90% and set extrusion width to 90%. May have printed even better with a slightly slower speed/lower width.

description.text:

The figure is sized ~5 cm since I will putt it on jpacek's "Gargoyle Fountain for 28mm RPG Games" (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2144984) which shall be filled with artificial water.
Keep in Mind, that the original "Honor of the Imperium" Staue, if you wanna use it by it self, without a fountain, is 6" / ~15 cm.

title: Corner Brackets for 25x25 and 25x50 mm 8020 Aluminum Extrusion
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Three different brackets are available for your printing pleasure. They all fit 25mm platform extruded aluminum profiles, I used 8020 but other brands should work fine.

  • 25x50mm outside bracket, takes 4 M6x25mm countersunk bolts
  • 25x25mm outside bracket, takes 2 M6x25mm countersunk bolts
  • 25x25mm inside bracket, takes 2 each M6x12 button bolts and M6 T-nuts

NOTE
Outside corner brackets need tapped center holes on your aluminum extrusions. You can order them pre-tapped (for a fee) or hand tap them yourself with a basic hand tapping set and tapping oil

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3km0QflF1DU

Here I am modeling (attempting to) an R/C Helicopter. This is loosely based off of the Outrage Velocity 50.

This project is mostly to see if I can model it close to the real thing.

This is a work in progress and will likely change multiple times as the process continues.

I have uploaded the main gear and auto gear STL files to show an example of the actual parts being modeled. I have printed these already to verify that they are the correct size.

Originally I was using Shapr3D, but I decided to sell my iPad Pro and use my desktop to model. I had one issue, I didn't know how to use any desktop modeling software. My first successful attempts at modeling was using Shapr3D. I owe a lot of credit to that app to getting me to where I am today.

I decided on Fusion 360 it seems to be a complete solution with lots of tutorials on YouTube. After watching many tutorials I have been able to learn Fusion 360 enough that I could start this project over.

All images you see are modeled in Fusion 360.

I remixed the "name plate" to have a Raspberry Pi logo,
and I broke the posts on the rear fan bracket twice,
so added a small hole down thru to give strength by creating more walls.

Now, on my name plate I used 3 shells and 3 top/bottom layers and on the last top layer
watched for it to do the the 3 shells on the raspberry and outer edge, then turned off the printer when it went to do the fill so it created a kind of raised border.
Of course that ends up being the side without the rounded edges and smooth face from being on the glass, but I prefer the border look, or could have flipped it.

I used Tinkercad:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8Lh1NYD6XHw-pi-fan-h
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2FXC54cTalr-raspberry-name-plate

The built-in FET is generating heat during operation of the extruder or bed. I added a fan and tried forced air cooling. As of now, fans are running on separate power supplies. Adhesive tape and 16 mm tapping screw are necessary for fixing.

Attachment of the connector of the extruder is weak, and contact becomes worse. It became to fail to adjust the temperature of the extruder. It became shorter by about 1 cm, but stabilized by crimping 16P connector. To make it easier to pull out the connector, I attached a tie wrap.

Cover is necessary for this printer because it may peel off when laminating. An expensive cover is not necessary. A plastic bag is enough. However, it is hard to see. So, I will combine an OHP sheet with a polyethylene bag. Be careful not to cover the main board below. There is a problem with heat dissipation. Just pinching it in clothespins is enough.

The built-in SD card is 4 GB. In my printer SunDisk's one was used. Although it depends on the printer, since the SD card slot is manually soldered, there is a difference in proficiency by the operator. Due to this defect of soldering, an error may occur that the SD card can not read / write. It may be necessary to redo the soldering by experts. Repair by an amateur is actually simple, restoring by slightly deforming the soldered part of the SD card slot with a pin. It becomes a technique to mechanically deform the soldered part. Reliability according to crimping can be secured. The SD card itself can be used if you purchase a commercial product as it is and stab it. FAT16 would be a good format. Once height adjustment is done, it is recorded on the SD card. According to my trial and error, 8GB SD card could be used without problem. 32GB SD card was full of errors and could not be used.

The last picture is an example of fixing so that the bed does not come down.

title: Parametric OpenJSCAD vase/shade/case script
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Parametric OpenJSCAD https://openjscad.org/ scripted vase. You can use it for generate vases, lampshades and cases for travel (shugar, toothbrush, etc) or storage small parts.
Vase outline is summed sine wave(params: Number of z-waves, Z-waves phase) and parabola(params: d0, d1, d2) Wave amplitude is other parabolic function(params: ah0, ah1, ah2).
Circular waves is another parabolic amplitude(params: ar0, ar1, ar2) sine wave (params: Number of radial waves). Rotation angle have parabolic function too(params: wr0, wr1, wr2).
The argument of all parabolic functions is the z coordinate.
This calc help you define script params: https://goo.gl/RMFUcx (wait for diagram!)
vase.jscad and twisted_case.jscad have only different params.
I use SBS filament and spiral vase mode. For lamp shades set 0 top and bottom solid infill. For vases & cases bottom solid infill=3. Twisted case cap have 3-4mm more d0 param.
For best transparency I use 1.2mm nozzle, 0.4mm layer height and 1.8 extruder multiplier, and very low speed(5/6mm/sec for my Prusa).
Try solvent after printing for more transparency.

title: Capsules
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The range of 'Capsules' are fun and practical storage containers that look like a medicine capsule so can be configured in any combination of colors and will loo great!

Capsules come in a range of sizes for all sorts of different uses... including medications, cables, parts, small toys, nuts and bolts, jewellery... and lots more. There is an endless array of things that could be stored in a Capsule... so reusable as well and will make a great unique and fun gift as well. Plus... very handy to use when travelling to keep small items together and safe.

Sizes (approx.) are as follows:

50mm Inside Diameter - 140mm (Long ) / 100mm (Medium) / 65mm (Short)

32mm Inside Diameter - 140mm (Long ) / 100mm (Medium) / 65mm (Short)

FOB 10mm Inside Diameter - 70mm (Long) / 28mm (Short)

The joint between the 'a' and 'b' parts of the capsules is a press/snap fit. Well sliced files Capsule files printed on accurate / precise machines should result in a firm joint that won't come apart until you want it to.

The 'a' (male) side of the joint has a number of tabs that are inserted into the 'b' (female) side. These tabs allow clearance for compression to create a snap / secure fit. Once joined / seated correctly the two halves will rotate against each other but not come apart until pulled apart with a slight twist / snapping action. joint by snapping it away from the other part. Please note that the shorter versions are slightly harder to pull apart because there is less area to grip / hold onto them with... but with practice they are easy to close / open.

To make opening and closing easier it is recommended to apply a light lubricant to the mating surfaces so they slide past each other easier. Dry layered PLA can be surprisingly grippy... a single application of silicone lubricant is all it will need for the life of the capsule.

Capsules are easy prints but good build plate adhesion is critical due to the this contact area of each part on the build plate. For this reason a Raft is recommended to help hold the print secure by increasing the surface area on the build plate. A good, well formed Raft should snap away quickly / easily by hand.

Refer the print instructions and images for additional information... and please post images of your Capsules in use for other members to see. Have fun experimenting with color options!

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

PLA / 2 Shells / 20% or more infill recommended

Notes:

Capsules are easy prints but good build plate adhesion is critical due to the this contact area of each part on the build plate. For this reason a Raft is recommended to help hold the print secure by increasing the surface area on the build plate. A good, well formed Raft should snap away quickly / easily by hand.

Do not use automated support. No support is required. For best results good bridging is essential as is a filament fan (PLA).

The joint should be firm and secure when well sliced files are printed on accurate / precise well set up machines. However, not all machines and slicing apps work the same. If your joints are too loose / tight try uniformly scaling up or down a few percent to achieve the best fit for your machine. However, this should not be required in most cases.

Remove the Raft, add a lubricant to the mating surfaces then your Capsule is ready to use...

To make opening and closing easier it is recommended to apply a light lubricant to the mating surfaces so they slide past each other easier. Dry layered PLA can be surprisingly grippy... a single application of silicone lubricant is all it will need for the life of the capsule.

author: Veskari

title: Stretched Limo Anet A8 stock Spool Holder

description.text:
The stock Anet A8 spool holder is converted into a stretch limo version, the regular M8 type of rod is replaced by the T8 type of rod (500mm in the picture). The T8 type of rod is the same as the Z-rod in the Anet A8 printer.
The base rail comes with few types: the end bracket, the 100mm middle bracket, and the 200mm middle bracket. Each side of the rail needs 2 x end brackets, one or more of the middle brackets. The end brackets were made slightly shorter in order to have room for some end nuts. For instance, the 300mm T8 rod needs 2 end brackets, one 200mm rod in the middle per side (two sides required for the set). The brackets are tied together by M3 screws and nuts (M3 8mm or M3 12mm).
Now, the base rail itself will need some support, there are two type of rail supports: one is snapped underneath (type 1), and one is screwed into the rail (type 2). If you use the rail support type 2, then you need the longer M3 screws (maybe M3 16mm). The spool holder's end brackets with the little tabs can not hold many spools of filaments at 1kg each, at least one rail support bracket is needed.
A filament guide is provided to snap onto the rail to hold the filament in place when not in use, suggest to use the type of spool holder that uses the 608ZZ ball bearings (such as https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2476592)
The T8 rod will need spacer and end nuts (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2512596)
For long rods, the rod support might come in handy too (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2512926)
Printing:
It is strongly suggested to use as much infill as possible (70% or more) for the rail brackets, other pieces can be printed using 20% or 30% in fill.

description.text:
Update 10/7/17 I added a couple tips for dash cam use below.

This is a tool to help locate the pressure sensitive adhesive mounting plate (or strips) on the windshield for an A118 or B40 dash camera. For my cars, I used 3M Command Strips (a velcro-like fastener) rather than the mounting plate furnished with the camera because it is easier to make minor adjustments after the initial mounting.

Quick steps to use the tool:

  1. Attach the tool around the mounting face of the camera.
  2. Turn on the cam and use the display to find the best location for mounting.
  3. While holding the cam in the desired location, tape the tool to the glass and remove the camera.
  4. Affix the mounting plate or strips to the glass in the appropriate position within the tool frame with the pressure sensitive adhesive.
  5. Remove the tool frame from the glass and mount camera.

Using the tool:
It is a good idea to clean the glass with alcohol or other solvent in the area where the camera will be mounted to get the best adhesion. Place the tool around the window-mounting-surface of the camera (see photos) and attach a couple pieces of tape (masking tape is preferable) to the flanges on the tool at the sides of the camera.
Turn on the camera and, using the display, find the preferred mounting location on the glass. While the camera and tool are held in-place, press the pieces of tape against the glass and remove the camera from the frame, leaving the tool attached to the window glass.

Now, locate the mounting plate or command strips in the proper position within the frame of the tool and attach the adhesive to the glass. Remove the tool when the mounting device(s) are attached and make sure the adhesive is firmly pressed onto the glass.
FWIW, I've found that the 3M strips hold the camera firmly through summer temperatures and driving on rough roads.

A couple things I've found about dash cam use, YMMV:

  1. Probably most low priced dash cams have relatively crappy exposure systems, that can be tricked into underexposing the portion of the frame that you are really interested in, i.e. the traffic in front of you. For a lens as wide as is typically used in this camera (170 deg), this is a fairly narrow horizontal band, about a third of the vertical frame height. If you set the camera, so that this band is in the lower part of the frame, then they sky above the horizon occupies a major portion of the frame. On very cloudy days, under certain conditions, the cloudy sky dominates the exposure system and the traffic band can be grossly underexposed to the point where it can affect the usability of the image.
    An easy fix to reduce the chance of this happening is to rotate the lens downward so the traffic band is in the middle of the frame This results in the dashboard and hood of the car occupying the bottom third of the frame, but the traffic zone will not be overwhelmed by the variable sky brightness, and you will have better video most of the time.

  2. 1080 video is a big selling factor for these cameras, but it's worth trying 720 instead to see if it meets your needs. A few things that recording with 720 provides are:
    • More data on the memory card, twice the amount of recording time.
    • Lower processor load and less heating (think extreme summer).
    • Longer life of the memory card. Flash memory has a limited number of read/write cycles.
    • The lower resolution probably won't let you read license plates off the video, but 1080 might not either, most of the time.
    • Unless you are making a feature film, The 720 record will likely be sufficient for telling the story of unexpected events that unfold in front of you.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

any

Infill:

very little

Notes:

You can print this with very minimal settings as it will probably only be used one time and the tool can be very light-weight.
Some clean-up with a file or knife may be required to get the frame to fit over the window mounting surface of the camera.

title: Sand Bottle Holder for Clickgear Golf Cart

description.text: This is a much improved rework of www.thingiverse.com/thing:1718939. It is designed to hold the large sand bottles that a lot of courses use on carts but attaches to the attachment points on a Clickgear push cart. My original design just wasn't strong enough to stand up to the weight of a full sand bottle and the rigors of bouncing over the ground. This needs to be printed in a strong material - I used Polycarbonate and previously used Nylon, both of which are strong enough (and both can be challenging to print). I prefer the PC. In PC this is plenty strong and has been in use on my cart for quite a while with no problems. The picture also shows the assembly - all the pins are press fit and the design requires no other hardware.

author: kevinkahn

title: Virgin Pulse GoZone Pedometer battery cover.

description.text:
As in the description, it's the easy-to-lose battery cover to the HealthMiles' Gozone pedometer.  Ah, what the heck; included the version with the coin slot so you can tighten the cover with a quarter (HealthMiles3) along with the thumb-tighten only version (HealthMiles2).    
New version: HealthMiles4.  I raised the center inside a little to match the original battery cover more accurately; I finally borrowed one and measured it.  It fits like a glove, and I have had one in place for over half a year now.  
I have one more idea for improvement: add "Open" and "Closed" arrows to line up with the arrow on the pedometer body.  
If this helps you, please "Like." :-)

Print it solid. I think you can print it with raft; I haven't tried yet. You do need good adhesion, as curling will ruin it. The overhang is small, but you might still get a string or two. I gave it 4 layers and 100% fill, printed in PLA. You can tell by the first photo that it stuck a bit to my blue tape; I may have to re-level my plate.
I have printed the V.4 on Kapton, and it comes out nice and shiny, looking like something fresh from the factory. Bed alignment is crucial here.

title: Mini Filament Spool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a scaled down spool that should fit most spool holders. You can customize it however you would like to be able to fit nearly any needs. I know there are some designs out there that use less material, but I've tried them and none of them really worked great. They would catch on things, or were too weak, or they wouldn't fit right.
I have a lot of sample filaments that I have no good way of feeding them into the printer, so when I take one out of the bag it is in, I just slide it on the spool, snap the spool together, and it's ready to print.
You can have it generate both sides or choose which piece you want so you can print them individually. Filament holes for the ends can be adjusted, as well as the overall size of the spool, the hole, and the pegs that snap the two together.
If your filament is more than about 50g or so, I would suggest making the width a little higher.
I've also included the STL files for the default settings for both sides together and individually.

Edits:
v2: Changed tolerance on pegs to snap together tighter. Added holes for looping the filament through to start winding it.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
After Printing most of Drewlysses insert. it was very nice but didn't fit in the box the way I wanted (2 boards to fit flat) and couple other small tweaks. So I fired up inventor and redesigned the whole thing from scratch using drewlysses design as inspiration.

Everything is printed using 0.3 layers an 10% infill. It's an insert so I'm not over concerned with it looking super nice like to cut the material as much as possible. all said and done all the parts were 466 grams ( just bit over a pound)

Most of the files differ a little from the ones I printed. I fixed a couple of small problems in many of the files so they will work better and fill out the box better. city box and coin box tweaked so pieces are easier to get in and out

The following parts need multiples:

5 player boxs
6 resource boxes
2 forum boxes
2 player board spacers (just noticed this file is rotated weirdly sorry)

you can get by with out the player board support things. but they are only 12 grams and only take 30mins total to print both.

the Concordia spacer piece is also optional but helps stop stuff from shifting around

also added a little colony house file. I lost a black house at some point for that file I recommend 100% fill, 0.15 layers and a raft since its so small. it turned out great with the full fill it weighs about the same as the wood house you can barely tell it from the originals

The different color player boxes were a happy accident I ended up really liking but was a bit of a pain switching colors out every print. planned printing all in black but I wanted to print test first playerbox and was too lazy to swap out the blue which then gave me the idea to match each box to the player color.

also it is designed for holding 2 maps so if you don't have salsa it will still work but might shift around a bit so you might have to cut a piece of cardboard out for the bottom of the box to simulate a 2nd map

EDIT 9/10/17: Added revision to playerbox and card box to allow for sleeved cards.the originals may work but I think they would be very tight fit

EDIT: 9/23/17 shrunk resource a small bit so it works with sleeved card player boxes also.

check out my other custom inserts:

steam punk rally: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2441665

supermotherload: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2316396

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

10

Notes:

total print time was a bit over 48 hours used 466 grams of pla

used 0.8 walls (0.4 nozzle so 2 shells) and 0.9 top and bottom thickness

everything has nice big flat bottoms so no rafts or supports are needed

description.text: small spacer for front of RC car.

I wanted an enclosure for the UM2 that allowed the electronics to breathe more.

I had a hard time getting this to work. At first I tried to put all of the holes in the bottom face in the part model. But all those little perimeters made it difficult to print.

So I made the bottom side of the enclosure solid in the model.

In the slicer software (S3D), I set the number of top and bottom layers both to zero. And I set the number of shells to 10.

It didn't print perfect, but it printed better than any of my previous attempts.

Zero stop shim for athlon athlon argos btr 6-24x50 ffp. they go under the scope cap, shim from .20" to .38". DON'T PRINT THEM IN PLA, i don't want it to melt and stuck inside your scope

print_settings.Notes:: 0.2mm layers did almost work, but the threads came out perfect with 0.1mm - use as small layers as you can.

description.text: I recently got a Panavise and saw some helping hands attachments, but they were more than I wanted to spend so I designed my own. For the arms I bought 10 flexible arms for about $5 at https://www.aliexpress.com/item/WSFS-Hot-10PCS-Round-Nozzle-1-4PT-Flexible-Oil-Coolant-Pipe-Hose-Blue-Orange/32773128689.html plus alligator clips. The only other thing I needed was 3/4" long 1/4-20 screws for the base (I couldn't find that length so I bought some longer ones and cut them down). The threads for the arms are modeled into the design. I first printed the ring with 0.2mm layers and no supports and it did kind of work, but wasn't clean. I then reprinted with 0.1mm layers and no supports and it came out perfect, the threads work great. I designed a total of 9 arm mounting holes which should be overkill for anything, but gives lots of flexibility. For now I'm using CA glue to bond the clips inside the nozzle holes, but that may need a better solution.

comments.text: Hello, thanks for remixing your iPhone 7 case for those of us holding on to our 6's.  I printed this model with Hatchbox PLA at 0.2mm.  It took a little over 4 hours.  The case style is excellent and the fit was perfect for my phone.  However, the areas between the speaker and lightning connector holes cracked while I was removing support material.  One of the volume "buttons" also cracked while I cleaning it up.  I wasn't being too careful so these breaks could probably have been avoided.  I tend to get Christmas Morning Syndrom when I start prints before bedtime and just start tearing things off the printer when I wake up.
comments.author: varind

comments.text: Hi Varind, From what I've heard, Hatchbox prints great but is also a brittle PLA. Our iPhone 7 case is essentially the same case as this one and it's been on and off around 20 times with no problems. You still have to be careful but the cheap Esun PLA Plus I use works well. Hatchbox makes a pro version too so there's inexpensive options out there.

I have a tiny bit left and just printed off another one of your iPhone 6 Dotty cases.  It does seem to be a little more forgiving than the Hatchbox but after popping the phone in and out twice I broke a corner and a tab between the ringer switch and the corner. FULL DISCLOSURE: My phone has a super thin carbon fiber skin sticker around it.  It's possible that the edges of this caught on the case a bit while popping it in and out.

Thanks for testing out the model! Good news that everything lined up!
PETG is a wonderful plastic for its flexibility and toughness but it does have its weaknesses, which might be related to the fit problem.

title: More durable folding cube with hinge pins

description.text: I love emmett's folding cubes. But with my kids they get played with so much that the hinges don't last long. This is a simple hack to replace the cone and socket hinge with holes for hinge pins. The finished cube is comparatively indestructible. I printed at 125% in Makeware, then drilled the holes out just a tiny bit to 3mm. This is convenient as I have a large quantity of old 3mm filament. After assembly you can lock the pins in place with a soldering iron. You can learn more about this thing and others like it on "3D Printing Today" the podcast available on iTunes, or Stitcher radio or right from the source at http://threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com/

comments.text: Printed out perfectly without supports. I printed them at 110% so I wouldn't have to drill so much. I printed at 300 microns, 4 layers bottom, 3 outline layers, and 5 top layers without support and 0% infill. Material PLA. Speed was 3600mm/min. Extruder temps at 210C at 0.40mm diameter. I'll post in "Made" soon, I printed 6 cubes worth in just 24 hours.
comments.author: PepperNickel

comments.text: 100% size is almost perfect for 1.75MM filament as the hinge pin... will require a small amount of drilling, but it will fit very nicely.

description.text:
Designed this two piece stand to hold two Philips Sonicare toothbrush bases. Modeled after my original base holder, but updated to better fit the smaller base of the Diamond Series.

Outside of occasional sticking, the holder does a really good job at holding the bases in place.

This was created in Microsoft's 3D Builder.
The two files are the same thing. One is the STL file format, the other is 3D Builder's default format.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Fine

Infill:

light to medium

Notes:

I printed this on an XYZ DaVinci 2 3D printer using ABS. I printed mine in two different colors, one for each part.

It's best to print the two parts separate, that way you can change colors (if you want) and it will speed up the printing time.

Finishing

I used super glue to glue the two parts together.
Then I used clear nail polish to finish it (like a clear coat).
Though after doing this I learned about acetone vapor baths to finish 3D printed objects, which (if I had the need for another one) I would do this instead of the nail polish to get a more finished/professional look.

title: Anycubic Kossel Bowden Extruder Mod for flexible filament compatibility [may work]

description.text:
A part to replace the original extruder so that a 4mm PTFE tube could go right through, providing less open area for flexible filaments to curl.

To install....

  1. If your PTFE connector allows your PTFE tube to pass through, just screw in the connector with about 2 cm of the tube spiking out.
    OTHERWISE, cut out a short section (about 2 cm) of PEFE tube, after installing the connector, plug in the short tube from the other side.

  2. Use a hobby knife, or pliers, cut your spiking out PTFE tube into the triangular shape as shown.

  3. Assemble your extruder, make sure the bearing and the gear is not blocked by the tube.

Print with the orientation as in the stl file

author: 2Blairs

title: Decora single rocker switch with LED

description.text: This is a single button decora style wall switch to go along with my line of other decora style wall switches. This is a single paddle design with an LED indicator is designed to fit a standard decorator wall switch cover.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Introduction

For those that have seen my other switch designs, this is another one to add to that arsenal. This is a single paddle design much like a standard decaora style light switch. It has an LED indicator on it that can be used to indicate it's on/off status, or other identification purposes.

The circuit board

For my switch board designs I have designed a set of three circuit boards to create a fully functional home automation in-wall scene controller. The board that I am going to discuss here is the main switch circuit board. This board can be used not only for this design, but for my two button and four button on/off switches as well as my eight button scene controller. Depending how the switches and LEDs are populated on the board, you can create any of these switch configurations.

This design will fit a standard 30mm x 70mm prototyping board. This is the same style of proto board that I used when I made the first prototype versions of the switches. For the screws to hold the board to the switch plate I used 2mm x 5mm self tapping screws.

To read more about the design of these switches and the other circuit boards that go with them, check out my blog post on my website: https://dan.bemowski.info/2017/06/11/my-start-into-open-source-hardware/ You can also check out my thread on the MySensors forum website where I discuss everything from the original idea, to the prototypes, as well as where I am today with the project https://forum.mysensors.org/topic/4317/us-decora-style-wall-switch

More about me

For more information about me and other projects and things by me, take a look at my websirte at https://dan.bemowski.info/

title: Hypercube Evolution z axis adjustable optical endstop

description.text:
This z-axis optical endstop mount and adjuster was designed for the Hypercube Evolution (3030 aluminum profile) to adjust the bed height homing position. The design is compact and can be incorporated easily.

Two M5x10mm hex bolts w/ hammer nuts are required to mount the adjustment housing and optical endstop mount. There is a M3x25mm hex bolt and brass insert used to secure the sensor flag. For easier movement, passing a 3mm tap through the flag is reccommended. In addition, a drop of thread locking compound was used in the brass insert to lock the M3 bolt to the brass insert, thus allowing for the brass insert to spin without tightening.

Printer:

P3Steel

Rafts:

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

30%

author: dmtyer

description.text:
Update; Added top panel pictures in some random files generated while making them. I will add the solidworks files once everything is done and finalized.
I added the theme files as they are. IronMan.zip and warmachine.zip can be unzipped to your emulation station themes folder and then selected in the theme selection dialog in the es options menu.

I may change some stuff about the theme in the near future.

I updated the top panel to have a generous amount of space between buttons. I also resized everything to the proper proportions (36.5mm between centers at all times) I decided on 10 gauge galvanized steel (update: it turns out a1008 steel is cheaper and stronger so we've switched to that), and 1/8" inch lexan. The actual dimensions of those come to within .08 of a mm to flush with the top which is close enough for me. Sandpaper will make short work of the difference.

The bottom is going to be plexiglass 1/4" thick.

All that's left for the panel is to add the mounting screws.

An Iron Man (or War Machine) inspired raspberry pi, ps4 and pc compatible fightstick.
Includes everything (and I mean EVERYTHING) needed to play anywhere at any time.

The .stl is dimensionally accurate when exported with mm as the export unit in sketchup. The holes for the arcade buttons are 30mm diameter so that is one thing you could measure to check. I'd wait until the final versions are posted before using them though as there have been a few minor changes.

I've included a bunch of different versions and will probably split a couple off into their own things.

The IronManMK2.41Assembled.skp is the most up to date and complete version. It's also the only version with an accurate top panel atm.

The entire file reports as clean in the solids inspector and XEOMOTRY.com can read the step files generated with freecad from stls exported from sketchup.

Currently there are 4 thin walls where the side pockets meet with the side button cutouts. Leaving the corners rounded will give enough strength to keep the detail but you can cut it out too... The gcode files provided here currently do not cut out the thin walls.

The cheapest I found to print one was on 3d hubs for 246 dollars.
Don't even think about shapeways, they want over 1200 dollars for just the body.
3dSytems was downright rude when I told them my budget.

In the end I found a person in the CNC Zone Forums that hooked me up for 400 dollars for both CAM work included. I suggest that route (especially since the cam files are done already).

The text files included are actually the gcodes used to cnc the model. I'll add more of those as I get them.

The buttons this was modeled around are the ubiquitous sanwa obsf-30. I am planning on putting a Crown CWL-309MJ-KMS-ST25 but the cutout for it on the top panel is probably wrong. I haven't been able to find engineering drawings for that stick to properly size things (update: found the engineering drawings they are included in the photos now).

The layout of the buttons is very nonstandard. This is a Tekken fightstick and I learned to play claw originally (tekken players know what I'm talking about) so rather than relearn all that muscle memory the 4 main buttons are arranged like they are in the playstation controller. (In a diamond) The next 4 are positioned to so that an x is formed and two more are placed after that.

It's also a hitbox style controller so there are an extra 4 buttons on the face for that style of gameplay and ease of switching between the two playstyles (hitbox/joystick)

I've also included the artwork I had commissioned as well as the .psd files used in making it. Credit to TOVIO for some amazing work.

This artwork was created to look like me and my buddy that I am making a copy for.

I haven't looked through the psd files but you may be able to separate the face out into a separate layer and have your face put there instead of mine and my buddie's.

I used that artwork to make a custom theme for emulation station, which I will include later (once it's final and I can get some screenshots of it. ) I will try to get that uploaded to the official repo for themes.

Soon I will roll a custom image of retropie with a few neat little additions like google assistant integration, touch button motor control, safe shutdown button, and rgb led integration. When I do I will try to get it on here but if not I will at least have a link to it here.

Whew, that's a bunch and we haven't even gotten to the paintjob yet! (Candy marble red with gold leafing for iron man, black and silver leafing for war machine)

Not to mention the electronics! (of which there are many) I'll have to get to that in another update though.

If you like this project and would like to help out, please feel free to comment with your contact info and I am sure I can find something that could use the work.

If all this looks like way too much work (it is) and you would like me to design and build you a custom fightstick drop me a line at linkreincarnate AT gmail.com I'd be happy to help you make something amazing!
